questions.question_text: When using transaction, what is the default maximum span between events?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
default= -1

Selected Answer: A
maxpause
Syntax: maxpause=<int>[s | m | h | d]
Description: Specifies the maximum length of time in seconds, minutes, hours, or days for the pause between consecutive events in a transaction, which is the maximum total time between events. If the value is negative, the maxpause constraint is disabled and there is no limit.
Events must be sorted in descending chronological order before the maxpause argument is used. See the related example later in this topic.
Default: -1 (no limit)


https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/9.4.0/SearchReference/Transaction#:~:text=1%20(no%20limit)-,maxpause,-Syntax%3A%20maxpause

choices.B: Create or replace an existing field.
choices.D: Save SPL commands to be reused in other searches.
choices.C: Group transactions by one or more fields.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions can the eval command perform?

choices.A: Only in a large distributed Splunk environment.
choices.D: When grouping events results in over 1000 events in each group.
choices.C: When event grouping is based on start/end values.
choices.B: When calculating results from one or more fields.

discussion.content: When event grouping is based on start/end values.
C is correct answer .
Answer is C, B can be done with the more efficient stats command.
wow. will this exam be updated for correct answers? it's C!

Selected Answer: C
Only use "transaction" when you- Need to see events correlated together, 
- Must define event grouping based on start/end values or segment on time.
C Is the correct answer
Correct answer is C. Transactions are events that span time hence the Start/ End values

Selected Answer: C
The transaction command is most useful in two specific cases:

When a unique ID (from one or more fields) alone is not sufficient to discriminate between two transactions. This is the case when the identifier is reused, for example web sessions identified by cookie or client IP2.
When event grouping is based on start/end values

Selected Answer: B
To normalize data using the Splunk Common Information Model (CIM) Add-On, you need to ensure that the data being ingested has the correct sourcetypes configured. This helps the CIM to properly map the data to its predefined field names and structures. Once the sourcetypes are correctly set, the CIM can apply normalization and ensure that the data fits into the CIM schema.

questions.question_text: What needs to be configured in order to normalize data using the Splunk Common Information Model (CIM) Add-On?

choices.C: Configure event types that reference the appropriate tags.
choices.B: Configure the correct sourcetypes for the data models.
choices.A: Configure workflow actions for the event types.
choices.D: Configure field aliases to match tags in the data models.

choices.C: The events without the required field will not display in searches.
choices.B: The field being extracted will be required for all future events.
choices.A: The regex can no longer be edited.
choices.D: Only events with the required string will be included in the extraction.

discussion.content: D it's correct ans

Selected Answer: D
When performing a regular expression (regex) field extraction using the Field Extractor (FX), the require option can be used to focus the field extraction on events that contain specific text1. This means that only events with the required string will be included in the extraction.

Selected Answer: D
It is D. Language is right from the PDF.
Require option : extraction is only executed on events that include the highlighted string
